subject: Photography
title: Color Depth and Bit Depth
description: A 60-second lesson on Color Depth and Bit Depth.

hook.text: Your screen shows 16.7 million colors. The real world has infinite colors. Something's gotta give.

buildup.text: Bit depth measures how many shades a camera records. 8-bit files hold 256 shades per channel.

discovery.text: Higher bit depths â€” 12, 14, or 16-bit â€” capture more tonal information, especially in shadows and highlights.

twist.text: You can't see the difference on a standard monitor. But when editing, higher bit depth prevents banding and artifacts.

climax.text: RAW files preserve high bit depth. JPEGs compress to 8-bit. That's why RAW gives more editing flexibility.

punchline.text: More bits mean more colors â€” and more room to edit.

quiz.question: Why do photographers prefer RAW files over JPEG for editing?
options: RAW preserves higher bit depth giving more editing flexibility
